text:
When a waterlily beetle sees food on a pond’s
surface, it doesn’t swim, or soar. It water-skis.

Anchored to the water’s surface with its
claws, it lifts up its head, and starts flapping,

reaching speeds of up to half a meter per
second.

The beetle’s legs are hairy and waterproof,
but its claws are hair-free, allowing them

to stick under the water’s surface.
Thanks to the water’s rippling resistance,

traveling this way takes even more work than
flying through the air.

So why do it?
Researchers say it’s easier for the beetle

to find its favorite pond plants in two dimensions
rather than in three.
So not getting lost might outweigh the energy cost of skimming the surface.
